dialogue_turns.speaker: CEO of a major European bank
dialogue_turns.text: Why is it that American productivity has been growing at more than double the rate since 2006?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Why is it that American productivity has been growing at more than double the rate since two thousand six?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the two decades since 2004, US productivity growth, as measured by the value of output per hour worked, has been more than double that of the eurozone.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and that gap actually widened after the pandemic, right? US non-farm output per hour is up over 6 percent, while Europe's has flatlined or even dropped.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and that gap actually widened after the pandemic, right? U S non-farm output per hour is up over six percent, while Europe's has flatlined or even dropped.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whereas eurozone productivity has flat-lined and even fallen slightly since the outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic, US non-farm output per hour has risen by more than 6% over the same period more than adequate performance by Americas own historical standards.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And you know, some people point to the massive US fiscal stimulus as the reason, but that doesn't fully explain it. Stimulus might boost output, but not necessarily productivity.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And you know, some people point to the massive U S fiscal stimulus as the reason, but that doesn't fully explain it. Stimulus might boost output, but not necessarily productivity.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some accounts point to the strong fiscal stimulus applied in the US since the outbreak of the pandemic. But while strong spending stimulus can trigger rapid output and employment growth, it is not clear why it should produce faster productivity growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like, if anything, tight labor markets in the US should've forced companies to hire less productive workers, dragging output per hour down. But the opposite happened.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like, if anything, tight labor markets in the U S should've forced companies to hire less productive workers, dragging output per hour down. But the opposite happened.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On the contrary, given strong employment growth and tight labor markets, one might expect US companies to be forced to take on less productive workers, with negative implications for output per hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So what's going on? Maybe firms are substituting capital for labor— investing in automation because they just can't find workers. Think about how many places in the US now use QR codes for ordering or ATMs instead of tellers.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So what's going on? Maybe firms are substituting capital for labor- investing in automation because they just can't find workers. Think about how many places in the U S now use Q R codes for ordering or ATMs instead of tellers.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More likely, tight labor markets in the US may mean that firms, unable to find an adequate supply of workers at any price, are impelled to substitute capital for labor to invest in labor-saving technology. They are compelled to order meals, even at white-tablecloth restaurants, using a QR code.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then again, US productivity was already outperforming Europe in the decade before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't as tight. So it's not just a recent labor shortage story.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then again, U S productivity was already outperforming Europe in the decade before the pandemic, when labor markets weren't as tight. So it's not just a recent labor shortage story.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Recall, however, that US productivity growth had accelerated relative to Europes already in the decade leading up to the pandemic, when labor markets were not so tight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And it's not really about digital adoption timing either— US firms were ahead in tech use before the financial crisis, not so much recently. AI can't explain the last four years of strong growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it's not really about digital adoption timing either- U S firms were ahead in tech use before the financial crisis, not so much recently. A I can't explain the last four years of strong growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: US outperformance in computer producing and using sectors was most pronounced in the decade preceding the global financial crisis, not in the period since. In other words, AI and related developments cant explain Americas unusually strong productivity performance in the last four years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: So if it's not stimulus, not just labor markets, and not a tech advantage… what is holding Europe back? Unions resisting automation?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So if it's not stimulus, not just labor markets, and not a tech advantage... what is holding Europe back? Unions resisting automation?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: It could be that Europes strong trade unions, fearing job destruction, resist their adoption, although Germany, with a tradition of strong unions, has some of the most robot-intensive factories in the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Maybe, but Germany has strong unions and still uses tons of robots. Could be EU regulations— data privacy rules or proposed AI restrictions slowing things down.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Maybe, but Germany has strong unions and still uses tons of robots. Could be E U regulations- data privacy rules or proposed A I restrictions slowing things down.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The EUs data-privacy regulations, and now its proposed AI rulebook, if adhered to strictly, may slow the development of AI applications.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Or just plain bad luck— Putin's energy shock hit Europe way harder than the US, which is energy self-sufficient. Forced a lot of costly restructuring over there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Or just plain bad luck- Putin's energy shock hit Europe way harder than the U S, which is energy self-sufficient. Forced a lot of costly restructuring over there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The US, being self-sufficient in energy, has not been vulnerable to energy-supply disruptions to the same degree. European firms, in contrast, have been forced to suspend their most energy-intensive operations or else to engage in costly restructuring, which is not good for productivity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Mario Draghi's gonna present proposals later this year on this— capital markets union, removing barriers to competition…
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mario Draghi's gonna present proposals later this year on this- capital markets union, removing barriers to competition...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mario Draghi, Europes senior economic statesman, will present the EU with a set of proposals later this year for boosting productivity. No doubt, he will recommend completing Europes capital-markets union so that firms can more easily finance investments in new technologies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: …which are ideas we've heard for years. Europe needs to act on those, and maybe also come up with something new.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...which are ideas we've heard for years. Europe needs to act on those, and maybe also come up with something new.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Observers like me can confidently predict what Draghi will recommend because such proposals have been around for years. Europe should move now to implement these old ideas.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: 'Cause whatever they're doing now… it's clearly not working.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: 'Cause whatever they're doing now... it's clearly not working.

artist_script:
CEO of a major European bank: Why is it that American productivity has been growing at more than double the rate since 2006?
HostB: Yeah, and that gap actually widened after the pandemic, right? US non-farm output per hour is up over 6 percent, while Europe’s has flatlined or even dropped.
HostA: Exactly. And you know, some people point to the massive US fiscal stimulus as the reason, but that doesn’t fully explain it. Stimulus might boost output, but not necessarily productivity.
HostB: Right, like, if anything, tight labor markets in the US should’ve forced companies to hire less productive workers, dragging output per hour down. But the opposite happened.
HostA: So what’s going on? Maybe firms are substituting capital for labor— investing in automation because they just can’t find workers. Think about how many places in the US now use QR codes for ordering or ATMs instead of tellers.
HostB: But then again, US productivity was already outperforming Europe in the decade before the pandemic, when labor markets weren’t as tight. So it’s not just a recent labor shortage story.
HostA: And it’s not really about digital adoption timing either— US firms were ahead in tech use before the financial crisis, not so much recently. AI can’t explain the last four years of strong growth.
HostB: So if it’s not stimulus, not just labor markets, and not a tech advantage… what is holding Europe back? Unions resisting automation?
HostA: Maybe, but Germany has strong unions and still uses tons of robots. Could be EU regulations— data privacy rules or proposed AI restrictions slowing things down.
HostB: Or just plain bad luck— Putin’s energy shock hit Europe way harder than the US, which is energy self-sufficient. Forced a lot of costly restructuring over there.
HostA: Mario Draghi’s gonna present proposals later this year on this— capital markets union, removing barriers to competition…
HostB: …which are ideas we’ve heard for years. Europe needs to act on those, and maybe also come up with something new.
HostA: ‘Cause whatever they’re doing now… it’s clearly not working.
